ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt a lot in a fun environment.

In this course, I was able to further develop my reading and speaking skills. We read longer texts than in the lower Arabic level courses, and practiced speaking every class. We also dove deeper into more complex Arabic grammar concepts.

Building off the past two semesters of Arabic with more into culture across the Arab diaspora, more vocabulary and more grammar rules (nominative, accusative, genitive), and a lot more skills in conversational Arabic, we also practiced debates in Arabic

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: Prof. Elbousty is fantastic. The class was worth it just to get the chance to meet him. 
Weakness: I think that the course still needs greater emphasis on grammar.

Strengths: a very hands-on course, you will be speaking/reading/writing/listening A LOT in Arabic and so you will most likely learn A LOT if you pay attention. this of course pays off if you want to be immersed in the language. Elbousty is amazing at making sure everyone gets speaking, reading, and writing practice in Arabic and that everyone learns about Arab cultures
Weakness: the amount of work you'll be expected to do in and outside of class, could be difficult to get used to and you might have to do a little more independent study if you want to catch up

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If with Prof. Elbousty. I have had very poor experiences with other language professors in the Arabic department.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. If you have a drive to learn this beautiful language, you will likely find joy in the everyday work and conversations that take place in this course. This course is a step up from beginner level to intermediate, and it feels that way as well. Handling longer texts and more vocabulary may present as challenging at first, but I found my skills improving as the weeks went on.
I'd recommend this to anyone who really (emphasis on really) wants practice in conversational/academic modern standard Arabic. Otherwise, the time commitment would really be a struggle.
